golden-harvest-agro-industries-limited.inspectorNotes: This analysis of Golden Harvest Agro Industries Limited (GHAIL) for the years ended 30 June 2022 and 2023, based on the provided annual reports, reveals several areas of significant concern requiring regulatory attention. The 2022 audit opinion was qualified due to two main issues: 1) Non-distribution of Workers Profit Participation Fund (WPPF) of Taka 27,885,580 as per Labor Act 2006, and 2) Failure to convert share money deposit of Taka 48,355,038 into share capital within the required 6-month period as per FRC Circular. Additionally, the company had no policy or procedures for conducting impairment reviews of PPE, representing non-compliance with IAS 36. The 2023 audit opinion was also qualified due to continued WPPF non-compliance. Significant emphasis of matter was raised concerning the company's high reliance on short-term debt, constituting 72.44% of equity, and the consequent high finance costs which form 42% of total expenses. Financial performance shows a marginal net profit of BDT 3.99 million in 2023 compared to a substantial loss of BDT 101.16 million in 2022, though this improvement is largely attributed to a tax credit and profit share from associates. Liquidity and solvency ratios indicate heightened risk, with a deteriorating current ratio. The company's subsidiary, Golden Harvest Dairy Limited, is assessed as a going concern with material uncertainty. Key audit matters appropriately highlighted revenue recognition, PPE valuation, inventory, deferred tax, and consolidation. However, recurring issues in WPPF compliance and persistent high leverage warrant enhanced scrutiny. Corporate governance appears functional but is under pressure from financial stress. Overall, while the financial statements purport compliance with IFRS, the qualified audit opinions, significant financial risks, and identified non-compliances necessitate regulatory follow-up to ensure corrective actions are taken and future reporting integrity is maintained.

overview.description: Regulatory inspection of the Consolidated and Separate Financial Statements of Golden Harvest Agro Industries Ltd. and its subsidiaries for the years ended 30 June 2022 and 2023, prepared under International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). The 2022 financial statements were audited by MABS & J Partners, Chartered Accountants, while the 2023 financial statements were audited by S. F. Ahmed & Co., Chartered Accountants. The inspection focuses on compliance with IFRS, ISA, the Companies Act 1994, SEC Rules, and assesses financial health, audit quality, and corporate governance.

keyFindings.title: Qualified Audit Opinion Due to Regulatory Non-Compliance (2022)
keyFindings.description: Auditors issued a qualified opinion for 2022 because: 1) The company provided for Workers Profit Participation Fund (WPPF) of Taka 27,885,580 but had not distributed it among Employees Welfare Fund, Bangladesh Workers Welfare Fund, and WPPF in the mandated 80:10:10 ratio as per the Labor Act 2006; 2) The company provided Taka 48,355,038 as Share Money Deposit to Golden Harvest QSR Ltd., which was not converted into share capital within the required 6-month period as per FRC Circular No. 146/FRC/Admin/Circular/2020/01 dated 11 February 2020.
keyFindings.action: Issue directive to the company to immediately distribute the WPPF provision as per law and convert the share money deposit into share capital. Require restatement of the liability in the financial statements and verification by the auditor.

keyFindings.title: Qualified Audit Opinion Due to Regulatory Non-Compliance (2023)
keyFindings.description: Auditors issued a qualified opinion for 2023 because the company provided for BDT 34,774,853 towards Workers Profit Participation Fund (WPPF) but had not distributed it among Employees Welfare Fund, Bangladesh Workers Welfare Fund, and WPPF in the mandated 80:10:10 ratio as per the Labor Act 2006 (amended 2015).
keyFindings.action: Issue directive to the company to immediately distribute the WPPF provision as per law and restate the liability in the financial statements. Require the auditor to verify and report on compliance.

keyFindings.title: Non-Compliance with IAS 36 - Impairment of Assets (2022)
keyFindings.description: The company had no policy and procedures for conducting impairment review of Property, Plant and Equipment as required by IAS 36. No impairment test had been exercised by the company since inception of business or operation.
keyFindings.action: Require the company to establish proper impairment testing policies and procedures in accordance with IAS 36, and conduct retrospective impairment assessments where necessary.

keyFindings.title: Material Uncertainty Regarding Going Concern of Subsidiary
keyFindings.description: Management's note discloses that the financial statements of subsidiary Golden Harvest Dairy Ltd. are prepared on a going concern basis despite 'significant financial challenges that create a material uncertainty regarding its continuity.' These include sustained losses, high liabilities, and dependence on external financing.
keyFindings.action: Require the Board of GHAIL to submit a detailed turnaround plan and ongoing viability assessment for Golden Harvest Dairy Ltd. to the FRC for monitoring.

keyFindings.title: Excessive Reliance on Debt and High Financial Risk
keyFindings.description: The company's working capital is mainly financed by short-term loans. Total loans (BDT 1,951,570,716 in 2022) were 66.87% of shareholders' equity. Finance costs (BDT 112,002,129 in 2022) constituted 36% of total expenses (Administrative, Selling and Finance Expenses), indicating severe interest rate and refinancing risk.
keyFindings.action: Require the company to submit a formal debt restructuring and capital management plan. The Board should provide quarterly updates on covenant compliance and refinancing efforts to the FRC.

keyFindings.title: Weak Liquidity Position
keyFindings.description: The consolidated current ratio deteriorated from approximately 1.51 in 2022 to 1.54 in 2023. The acid-test ratio is approximately 1.13 (2023) and 1.09 (2022), indicating limited liquidity buffer after excluding inventory. Significant current liabilities against current assets pose a short-term solvency risk.
keyFindings.action: Direct the company's audit committee to oversee enhanced working capital management and cash flow forecasting. Review the terms and renewal status of short-term credit facilities.

findings.title: Non-Compliance with Bangladesh Labor Act, 2006 (Amended 2015)
findings.description: Company accrued BDT 27,885,580 (2022) and BDT 34,774,853 (2023) for Workers Profit Participation Fund (WPPF) but failed to distribute it into the three mandated funds (Employees Welfare, Bangladesh Workers Welfare, WPPF) in the 80:10:10 ratio, as required by law.
findings.action: Issue a directive under the Financial Reporting Act, 2015, requiring the company to: 1. Immediately distribute the accrued WPPF amounts as per law. 2. Submit proof of distribution to the FRC and the auditor. 3. Restate the relevant liability line items in its next financial statements with a note explaining the correction. 4. Review and strengthen its internal controls over statutory compliance.

findings.title: Non-Compliance with FRC Circular No. 146/FRC/Admin/Circular/2020/01
findings.description: Company provided Taka 48,355,038 as Share Money Deposit to Golden Harvest QSR Ltd. which was not converted into share capital within the required 6-month period as per the FRC Circular.
findings.action: Require the company to immediately convert the share money deposit into share capital and submit evidence of conversion to the FRC. Impose penalty for non-compliance with FRC directive.

findings.title: Non-Compliance with IAS 36 - Impairment of Assets
findings.description: Company had no policy and procedures for conducting impairment review of Property, Plant and Equipment. No impairment test had been exercised since inception of business, representing material non-compliance with IFRS.
findings.action: Require the company to: 1. Establish proper impairment testing policies and procedures in accordance with IAS 36. 2. Conduct retrospective impairment assessments for relevant periods. 3. Engage an independent expert to validate the impairment testing methodology. 4. Restate financial statements if material impairments are identified.

findings.title: Inadequate Disclosure and Plan for Subsidiary's Going Concern
findings.description: While management acknowledges material uncertainty regarding the going concern of Golden Harvest Dairy Ltd., the disclosures and the outlined mitigating measures are generic. A detailed, credible, and monitored turnaround plan is absent from the public report.
findings.action: Require the Board of GHAIL to prepare and submit to the FRC, within 30 days, a comprehensive, board-approved viability plan for Golden Harvest Dairy Ltd., including detailed cash flow projections, debt restructuring negotiations, capital injection plans, and monthly monitoring milestones. The FRC will review this plan quarterly.

findings.title: Unchecked Escalation of Financial Leverage
findings.description: The company's debt-to-equity ratio increased from 0.77 to 0.82, with total loans at 66.87% (2022) and 72.44% (2023) of equity. The 'Emphasis of Matter' by the auditor highlights an unsustainable capital structure heavily reliant on short-term debt, exposing the company to severe refinancing and interest rate risk.
findings.action: 1. Require the company's audit committee to commission an independent review of its capital structure and long-term financing strategy. 2. Direct the company to engage with its lenders to formalize a medium-term debt restructuring plan and submit a copy to the FRC within 60 days. 3. Impose a condition that any further significant borrowing requires prior notification to the FRC.

materiality.qualitative: High - Fundamental accounting standard non-compliance affecting asset valuation.

materiality.impact: Threatens continuity of operations, increases cost of capital, limits strategic flexibility.
materiality.quantitative: Total loans BDT 1,951.57 million (2022) and BDT 2,086.73 million (2023). Finance cost BDT 112.00 million (2022) and BDT 145.42 million (2023).
materiality.qualitative: Pervasively Material - Impacts the entity's ability to continue as a going concern, a fundamental assumption in financial reporting.

actions.action: Formal letter to the Board of Directors detailing the findings and requiring specific corrective actions on WPPF distribution, share money deposit conversion, IAS 36 compliance, debt management, and subsidiary viability.
Request detailed board minutes, cash flow forecasts, lender correspondence, impairment testing documentation, and the subsidiary's latest management accounts.
Schedule a follow-up inspection in Q4 2024 to assess implementation of corrective actions, financial restructuring progress, IAS 36 compliance, and the subsidiary's status.
Initiate proceedings for imposing penalties under the Financial Reporting Act, 2015 for repeated non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
